description: Borrowed from Latin consolidātus, from the verb consolidō, from solidus (“solid”).

adjectives.description: consolidate (comparative more consolidate, superlative most consolidate)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Formed into a solid mass; made firm; consolidated.
examples: A gentleman [should learn to ride] while he is tender and the brawns and sinews of his thighs not fully consolidate.

verbs.description: consolidate (third-person singular simple present consolidates, present participle consolidating, simple past and past participle consolidated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To combine into a single unit; to group together or join.
examples: He consolidated his luggage into a single large bag.

entries.meaning: To make stronger or more solid.
(finance) With respect to debt, to pay off several debts with a single loan.
